title: My Weird Jar of Beef Fat: The Bourbon Vanilla Tallow Balm That Actually Works
body:
Okay so. I bought beef fat for my face. I know. It sounds like something you’d find in a weird corner of the internet, or like a prank. My friend Sam literally said “you’re putting what on your skin?” when I told her. She made a face. I get it. The whole idea of tallow skincare, like, beef tallow for your face, sounds medieval. Or gross. Or both. But my skin last winter was a disaster. Like, tight, flaky, angry disaster. I’d tried the expensive stuff, the stuff in the fancy jars that cost more than my electric bill. It just sat there. Or made things red. So I was scrolling Etsy one night, it was late, like 1 AM, and my hands were so dry they hurt to bend. I found this little shop. Whipped tallow balm. Bourbon Vanilla scent. I stared at it. Beef fat. For my face. I almost closed the tab. But then I thought, what’s the actual worst that could happen? I’m already miserable. So I clicked buy.

It arrived in this simple jar. No crazy packaging. I opened it in my kitchen, under the weird yellow-ish light. My cat was watching me. Judging me, probably. I smelled it first. I was braced for, I don’t know, a barnyard. Or gravy. It wasn’t that. It was warm. Like a vanilla candle but not sweet. Deeper. Cozy. The texture was… weird. Not bad weird. Solid but soft. I scooped a tiny bit. Rubbed it between my fingers and it just melted. Like it became oil instantly. I put it on the back of my hand. It soaked in. Fast. No greasy film. My skin just… drank it. And it felt better. Immediately. The tightness was gone. I stood there in my kitchen, smelling my hand, confused. This beef fat thing might not be a prank.

## How I Started Putting Tallow on My Face (And Why It’s Not Crazy)

Look. I had to google “is tallow good for skin” after I bought it. Because I needed to justify this to myself. The science, or what I understood of it while eating cereal at 8 AM, made a stupid amount of sense. Our skin produces sebum, right? That’s our natural oil. Tallow from grass-fed cows is apparently really close to that. Like, structurally similar. So your skin recognizes it. It doesn’t just sit on top like a plastic wrap—it gets in there. It’s not like putting motor oil on your face. It’s more like giving your skin something it already knows how to use. This balm is whipped, which just makes it fluffy and easy to scoop. And it’s from France, which made me feel fancy about my jar of beef fat. The whole “beef tallow skincare” thing started making sense. It’s not a new weird trend. It’s an old thing. People used it forever. We just forgot.

My first time using it on my face, I was nervous. I did a patch test on my jaw. Waited. Nothing happened. No red bumps. No screaming pores. So I went for it. After I washed my face, I took a little dab. Maybe the size of a pea. Warmed it up. Pressed it in. My skin felt… calm. Not shiny. Not sticky. Just calm. Like it finally took a deep breath after holding it all winter. I woke up the next day and my cheeks weren’t sandpaper. That hadn’t happened in months. I kept using it. Morning and night. The jar from that Etsy shop, the one with the simple label, just lived on my bedside table next to my water glass and a pile of receipts.

## What This Bourbon Vanilla Stuff Actually Does

The scent is the thing you notice first. It’s not food vanilla. It’s not a bakery. It’s bourbon vanilla, which is warmer. Smokier almost. It doesn’t smell like dessert. It smells like a cozy blanket. Or like a old library with a fireplace. Something about it is just… stress-reducing. I’d put it on before bed and just take a second to breathe it in. My bedroom would smell like it faintly. In a good way. Not overpowering. Just a little comforting cloud.

But the real magic is what it does for dry skin. My elbows were a lost cause. Seriously. Rough, scaly, I was embarrassed to wear long-sleeve shirts because they’d catch on the fabric. I started slathering this tallow balm on them at night. After a week, they were different. Not perfect. But touchable. After two, they were actually smooth. I showed my partner. He was impressed. And he thinks most of my skincare stuff is voodoo. My knuckles stopped cracking and bleeding. My heels, which get brutal in winter, softened up. I used it on a windburned patch on my cheek after a stupidly cold walk—gone in two days. It’s like this one jar fixed every dry spot I had. It just… works. I don’t have a better word. It absorbs and fixes the problem.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Beef Fat Experiment

So I’ve been using it for a while now. I’m on my second jar. That’s the real review, right? You don’t buy a second one if it sucks. My skin texture is different. It’s not “perfect” because I’m 35 and I drink coffee and don’t sleep enough. But the fine lines around my eyes, the ones that look worse when I’m dehydrated, are less… noticeable. They’re still there. But they’re softer. My skin just looks more even. Healthier. Not “glowing” in that weird Instagram way. Just like it’s properly hydrated for the first time in years. It doesn’t feel tight an hour after I wash it. It doesn’t freak out when the weather changes.

I even started using a tiny bit as a final step over my serum in the morning. Under makeup. It doesn’t pill. It just makes my foundation sit better. Like my skin isn’t sucking all the moisture out of it. I told my mom about it. She’s in her 60s and her skin gets so dry in winter it itches. I got her a jar for her birthday. She called me two weeks later, confused and happy. “What is in this stuff?” she asked. “My hands haven’t felt this good since I was a kid.” That’s the thing. It’s simple. It’s one ingredient, basically, whipped into a balm. There’s no list of 50 chemical names. It’s just… tallow. And it works better than the complicated stuff.

## Would I Buy This Tallow Balm Again? And Other Questions

Yeah. Obviously. I already did. I’ll probably buy a third when this one runs low. It’s become a non-negotiable in my bathroom. For the price, it lasts forever. You need so little. My first jar lasted me almost three months using it on my face, hands, and dry patches. That’s cheaper than any fancy moisturizer I’ve ever bought that didn’t work half as well.

Anyway my coffee is getting cold. I’m sitting here typing this with my elbows on the table and they’re not catching on the wood. That’s the proof, I guess.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, it can be. Sounds wild, but it makes sense if you think about it. Our skin’s natural oil and tallow are similar. So for a lot of people, especially with dry or sensitive skin, it absorbs really well and doesn’t cause problems. It’s like giving your skin something it already knows.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
It hasn’t for me. And I can get clogged pores pretty easy. Because it’s so similar to our own sebum, it seems to sink in instead of sitting on top and blocking things. But everyone’s skin is different. Always patch test!

**What does the Bourbon Vanilla tallow balm smell like?**
It’s warm. Like a vanilla bean pod, not vanilla ice cream. There’s a depth to it. It’s cozy and comforting, not sugary. It’s my favorite part, honestly. Makes the whole routine feel like a treat.

So yeah. If your skin is being difficult, or you’re just curious about this whole beef tallow skincare thing, this balm might be worth a shot. It was for me. I got past the weirdness and now I just have a jar of stuff that works. And my skin’s happy. That’s all I wanted.
